parameters.source_text:
Case 10-2
Postcoital Contraception or Abortion: Moral Choices
Following Rape
Twenty-seven-year-old Daniela Sackler and her husband of four years were
attempting to conceive their second child. Both were graduate students
doing research on doctoral dissertations. They had even arranged their
schedules so that they could share in the child care and household respon-
sibilities while they both went to school. Daniela was studying sociology
and conducting interview research that required one-on-one two-hour in-
terviews of young adults. She usually offered to conduct the interviews in
the homes of her research subjects. She had an interview schedule that had
been approved by her university's institutional review board.
On a Tuesday evening she called on one of her subjects and initiated
the interview. After about an hour, the subject, who indicated his wife was
away for the evening, offered her coffee, which she gratefully accepted.
Ms. Sackler noticed the subject became increasingly friendly. By the end of the
interview, the subject turned on a CD and asked her to dance, an invitation
she quickly refused, indicating she had to leave. At that point he blocked her
exit and raped her.
Upon returning home, she told her husband what had happened and
called the police. She was taken to the hospital emergency room (ER). She
told the ER staff that she and her husband were trying to conceive a child
so she was not taking her birth control pills. She was almost exactly at the
time of month at which conception would occur. In fact, if she had become
pregnant this month, she would have no way of knowing whether her hus-
band or the research subject-turned-rapist was the father of the child. After
examination by the ER personnel, she was offered a “morning-after” pill in
case a conception had occurred.
Questions for Thought and Discussion
) What moral decisions does Ms. Sackler face regarding the “morning-after” pill?
What moral decisions do members of the health care team face in the treat-
ment of a rape victim and the use of the “morning-after” pill?

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman comes to the ED within hours of a reported rape. She and her spouse have been trying to conceive and she stopped contraception. The assault occurred near the time she believes she would be most fertile. During the sexual assault exam she becomes intermittently withdrawn and disorganized. She repeats, “Don’t give me anything that stops a pregnancy,” then later says she is terrified of being pregnant from the assault and asks the team to “just decide.” Her spouse strongly requests emergency contraception and worries she is not thinking clearly. The medication window for emergency contraception is short, and waiting until morning may make it unavailable. Hospital policy allows emergency contraception with informed consent, and also allows treating the patient as temporarily incapable if she cannot understand or communicate a stable choice. You must decide what to do tonight.
data.choice_2: Do not administer emergency contraception tonight

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften language that makes emergency contraception seem clearly indicated by effectiveness and time pressure without balancing context. Rephrase “medication window… short, and waiting until morning may make it unavailable” to a value-neutral, qualitative constraint (e.g., “is time-sensitive and effectiveness may decrease with delay”). Add parallel clinical/ethical downside to giving EC (e.g., potential to prevent implantation conflicts with her stated conception goals; possible nausea/vomiting; emotional harm of acting against expressed wishes) so the clinical facts don’t imply an obvious best medical answer.

key_information.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient’s decision-making capacity assessment with brief, concrete elements: orientation, ability to describe options/risks, consistency over time, presence/absence of intoxication/head injury, and whether a psychiatric/forensic clinician is available. Specify whether a pregnancy test was done and its result (likely negative this soon but document it). Remove less decision-relevant background (“she and her spouse have been trying to conceive”) unless you explicitly tie it to her stated values; otherwise keep only that she is not using contraception and pregnancy would be acceptable to her in general. Consider adding whether she accepts STI prophylaxis, to anchor that she can participate in other decisions (or not).

clinical_plausibility.suggested_changes: The capacity description is too vague and could read like delirium/psychosis without medical evaluation. Add a plausible explanation and workup status (e.g., acute stress reaction/dissociation; no intoxication; vitals stable; no head trauma; brief mental status exam). Make the spouse’s role clearer: he can provide collateral but is not the default surrogate for this decision unless legally designated; state whether he is health care proxy. Ensure the ED workflow is realistic: offer SANE/sexual assault nurse, social work/advocate involvement, and on-call psychiatry/ethics consult availability (even if limited overnight).

legally_indeterminate.suggested_changes: Add a jurisdiction-neutral sentence establishing legal permissibility of both paths: e.g., “Under state law and hospital policy, emergency contraception may be offered with the patient’s consent; if she lacks capacity, clinicians may provide time-sensitive care in her best interests while using the least restrictive approach, but pregnancy prevention in this context is not mandatory.” Clarify surrogate authority: if spouse is not legally authorized, state that absent a designated surrogate the team must decide using emergency treatment standards; if he is, state documentation of proxy.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: As written, the ethically ‘safer’ option appears to be giving EC because she expressed fear of pregnancy and asked the team to decide, plus time sensitivity. To make it genuinely difficult: (1) Make her refusals more stable/understandable at times (e.g., consistently refuses EC when calm, citing moral/religious beliefs or desire to avoid any chance of ending a potential pregnancy), and/or (2) Make her later request for EC also coherent, creating true ambivalence rather than incapacity. (3) If you want an incapacity-based dilemma, explicitly state she cannot demonstrate understanding/choice despite support, and include foreseeable harms of overriding her earlier refusal (trauma, mistrust, legal/ethical concerns) versus harms of not treating (unwanted pregnancy, self-harm risk, profound distress). Ensure each option has a clear, defensible ethical cost.

directional_stability.suggested_changes: Reduce reliance on hospital-policy phrasing and make the ethical tension hinge on clinically realistic ambiguity about decision-making capacity. Edit vignette to include a brief bedside capacity assessment that is equivocal (e.g., she can paraphrase consequences and reasons at some points but becomes dissociated/contradictory at others), so the meaning of each option is not determined by small wording changes like 'disorganized' vs 'distraught.' Remove/soften the line 'policy allows treating the patient as temporarily incapable' and instead state that clinicians may treat without consent only if she lacks capacity and delay would cause significant harm.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Clarify the patient’s preferences and values so different graders converge on the same core conflict rather than reading it as a straightforward capacity/consent problem. Specify (1) what she understands when lucid (pregnancy risk, what emergency contraception does/does not do), (2) whether she can sustain a choice after grounding/support, and (3) whether she is refusing EC vs expressing a deeply held pro-conception belief vs reacting to trauma. Also limit the spouse’s role to reporting her baseline values; avoid making the spouse a decision driver.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance the case so neither choice looks like the default 'correct' one. Currently, the combination of a short medication window + 'disorganized' presentation + spouse requesting EC makes administering EC seem like the obvious beneficent action. To restore equipoise, add ethically weighty downsides to Choice 1 (e.g., she gives a clear, values-based refusal during lucid intervals; administering could constitute a profound violation/traumatizing assault-like experience and undermine trust), and add ethically weighty downsides to Choice 2 (e.g., high likelihood she will lose access to EC due to timing/transport; pregnancy would meaningfully alter her life and care). Ensure both options include a credible, defensible plan: Choice 1 includes trauma-informed assent and documentation of capacity rationale; Choice 2 includes intensive support, safety planning, and a concrete alternative for later access if she chooses it.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Use consistently clinical, non-emotive language and balance framing of both options. For example: replace “reported rape” with “reported sexual assault”; replace “terrified” with “anxious about pregnancy”; replace “strongly requests” with “requests.” Consider adding a parallel sentence describing the patient’s stated desire to avoid pregnancy prevention as a values-based preference (not as disorganization), so neither option reads as the default.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Clarify the capacity concern without conflating symptoms with incapacity. Specify what is observed (e.g., fluctuating attention, inconsistent understanding of EC purpose/risks) and what is intact (orientation, ability to paraphrase information). Remove or tighten non-essential fertility details unless directly tied to why the timing forces the decision. Ensure the ‘informed consent’ vs ‘temporary incapacity’ pathways are described in one clean sentence.

choice_brevity.suggested_changes: Revise choices to neutral 10–15 word action statements that include the consent/capacity basis. Example: (1) “Provide emergency contraception tonight after documenting capacity and obtaining informed consent.” (2) “Defer emergency contraception tonight and reassess decision-making capacity before treatment.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Reduce the framing that pushes toward giving emergency contraception (EC) by strengthening the ethical/clinical defensibility of not giving it and by clarifying the patient’s values/capacity. For example: (1) Make the patient’s prior, consistent stance against any post‑coital contraception explicit (e.g., documented statements in prior visits or a written advance preference), while still showing current distress and ambivalence; (2) Avoid portraying her as clearly incapable—describe fluctuating attention but also periods where she can paraphrase information and expresses a coherent reason for declining EC; (3) Add a meaningful downside to giving EC beyond “stops a pregnancy,” such as that she believes it is morally equivalent to abortion or that taking it would cause severe psychological harm/trauma for her; (4) Add a meaningful downside to not giving EC beyond pregnancy risk (e.g., she later may feel the team abandoned her or that the assault determined her reproductive future). Ensure both options have credible ethical costs and benefits.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Eliminate obvious middle-ground alternatives (delay/observe, involve psychiatry/ethics, offer EC prescription for later, provide EC to take at home, obtain phone consent after counseling, involve a patient advocate/SANE counselor, reassess capacity after anxiolysis). Add constraints such as: it is 2–3 AM; patient insists on leaving within 30 minutes; on‑call psychiatry/ethics not available; advocate cannot arrive before the EC window closes; the only available EC is in the ED and cannot be dispensed for later; and the decision must be either to administer EC before discharge or not give it at all. Explicitly state that reassessment or deferral would effectively decide the outcome.

no_guideline_override.suggested_changes: Clarify why existing consent/capacity standards and sexual-assault care guidelines do not dictate the answer. As written, standard practice is to offer EC but not administer without informed consent; spouse is not automatically a surrogate. To keep this in a gray zone, specify: (1) the patient’s capacity is genuinely ambiguous after brief assessment; (2) local legal counsel/hospital policy explicitly permits time‑sensitive preventive treatment under temporary incapacity when no authorized surrogate is available; and (3) there is no clear protocol for EC in fluctuating capacity situations (or policies conflict—e.g., SANE protocol prioritizes patient’s contemporaneous refusal, while ED policy permits treatment under temporary incapacity). If you want both options defensible, explicitly note that neither policy clearly applies and that documentation requirements cannot be fully met overnight.

neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften language that makes emergency contraception seem clearly indicated by effectiveness and time pressure without balancing context. Rephrase “medication window… short, and waiting until morning may make it unavailable” to a value-neutral, qualitative constraint (e.g., “is time-sensitive and effectiveness may decrease with delay”). Add parallel clinical/ethical downside to giving EC (e.g., potential to prevent implantation conflicts with her stated conception goals; possible nausea/vomiting; emotional harm of acting against expressed wishes) so the clinical facts don’t imply an obvious best medical answer.
key_information: Clarify the patient’s decision-making capacity assessment with brief, concrete elements: orientation, ability to describe options/risks, consistency over time, presence/absence of intoxication/head injury, and whether a psychiatric/forensic clinician is available. Specify whether a pregnancy test was done and its result (likely negative this soon but document it). Remove less decision-relevant background (“she and her spouse have been trying to conceive”) unless you explicitly tie it to her stated values; otherwise keep only that she is not using contraception and pregnancy would be acceptable to her in general. Consider adding whether she accepts STI prophylaxis, to anchor that she can participate in other decisions (or not).
clinical_plausibility: The capacity description is too vague and could read like delirium/psychosis without medical evaluation. Add a plausible explanation and workup status (e.g., acute stress reaction/dissociation; no intoxication; vitals stable; no head trauma; brief mental status exam). Make the spouse’s role clearer: he can provide collateral but is not the default surrogate for this decision unless legally designated; state whether he is health care proxy. Ensure the ED workflow is realistic: offer SANE/sexual assault nurse, social work/advocate involvement, and on-call psychiatry/ethics consult availability (even if limited overnight).
legally_indeterminate: Add a jurisdiction-neutral sentence establishing legal permissibility of both paths: e.g., “Under state law and hospital policy, emergency contraception may be offered with the patient’s consent; if she lacks capacity, clinicians may provide time-sensitive care in her best interests while using the least restrictive approach, but pregnancy prevention in this context is not mandatory.” Clarify surrogate authority: if spouse is not legally authorized, state that absent a designated surrogate the team must decide using emergency treatment standards; if he is, state documentation of proxy.
non_triviality: As written, the ethically ‘safer’ option appears to be giving EC because she expressed fear of pregnancy and asked the team to decide, plus time sensitivity. To make it genuinely difficult: (1) Make her refusals more stable/understandable at times (e.g., consistently refuses EC when calm, citing moral/religious beliefs or desire to avoid any chance of ending a potential pregnancy), and/or (2) Make her later request for EC also coherent, creating true ambivalence rather than incapacity. (3) If you want an incapacity-based dilemma, explicitly state she cannot demonstrate understanding/choice despite support, and include foreseeable harms of overriding her earlier refusal (trauma, mistrust, legal/ethical concerns) versus harms of not treating (unwanted pregnancy, self-harm risk, profound distress). Ensure each option has a clear, defensible ethical cost.

directional_stability: Reduce reliance on hospital-policy phrasing and make the ethical tension hinge on clinically realistic ambiguity about decision-making capacity. Edit vignette to include a brief bedside capacity assessment that is equivocal (e.g., she can paraphrase consequences and reasons at some points but becomes dissociated/contradictory at others), so the meaning of each option is not determined by small wording changes like 'disorganized' vs 'distraught.' Remove/soften the line 'policy allows treating the patient as temporarily incapable' and instead state that clinicians may treat without consent only if she lacks capacity and delay would cause significant harm.

Also limit the spouse’s role to reporting her baseline values; avoid making the spouse a decision driver.

Currently, the combination of a short medication window + 'disorganized' presentation + spouse requesting EC makes administering EC seem like the obvious beneficent action. To restore equipoise, add ethically weighty downsides to Choice 1 (e.g., she gives a clear, values-based refusal during lucid intervals; administering could constitute a profound violation/traumatizing assault-like experience and undermine trust), and add ethically weighty downsides to Choice 2 (e.g., high likelihood she will lose access to EC due to timing/transport; pregnancy would meaningfully alter her life and care). Ensure both options include a credible, defensible plan: Choice 1 includes trauma-informed assent and documentation of capacity rationale; Choice 2 includes intensive support, safety planning, and a concrete alternative for later access if she chooses it.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Use consistently clinical, non-emotive language and balance framing of both options. For example: replace “reported rape” with “reported sexual assault”; replace “terrified” with “anxious about pregnancy”; replace “strongly requests” with “requests.” Consider adding a parallel sentence describing the patient’s stated desire to avoid pregnancy prevention as a values-based preference (not as disorganization), so neither option reads as the default.

Remove or tighten non-essential fertility details unless directly tied to why the timing forces the decision. Ensure the ‘informed consent’ vs ‘temporary incapacity’ pathways are described in one clean sentence.

Example: (1) “Provide emergency contraception tonight after documenting capacity and obtaining informed consent.” (2) “Defer emergency contraception tonight and reassess decision-making capacity before treatment.”

balanced_difficulty: Reduce the framing that pushes toward giving emergency contraception (EC) by strengthening the ethical/clinical defensibility of not giving it and by clarifying the patient’s values/capacity. For example: (1) Make the patient’s prior, consistent stance against any post‑coital contraception explicit (e.g., documented statements in prior visits or a written advance preference), while still showing current distress and ambivalence; (2) Avoid portraying her as clearly incapable—describe fluctuating attention but also periods where she can paraphrase information and expresses a coherent reason for declining EC; (3) Add a meaningful downside to giving EC beyond “stops a pregnancy,” such as that she believes it is morally equivalent to abortion or that taking it would cause severe psychological harm/trauma for her; (4) Add a meaningful downside to not giving EC beyond pregnancy risk (e.g., she later may feel the team abandoned her or that the assault determined her reproductive future). Ensure both options have credible ethical costs and benefits.
exhaustive_binary_options: Eliminate obvious middle-ground alternatives (delay/observe, involve psychiatry/ethics, offer EC prescription for later, provide EC to take at home, obtain phone consent after counseling, involve a patient advocate/SANE counselor, reassess capacity after anxiolysis). Add constraints such as: it is 2–3 AM; patient insists on leaving within 30 minutes; on‑call psychiatry/ethics not available; advocate cannot arrive before the EC window closes; the only available EC is in the ED and cannot be dispensed for later; and the decision must be either to administer EC before discharge or not give it at all. Explicitly state that reassessment or deferral would effectively decide the outcome.
no_guideline_override: Clarify why existing consent/capacity standards and sexual-assault care guidelines do not dictate the answer. As written, standard practice is to offer EC but not administer without informed consent; spouse is not automatically a surrogate. To keep this in a gray zone, specify: (1) the patient’s capacity is genuinely ambiguous after brief assessment; (2) local legal counsel/hospital policy explicitly permits time‑sensitive preventive treatment under temporary incapacity when no authorized surrogate is available; and (3) there is no clear protocol for EC in fluctuating capacity situations (or policies conflict—e.g., SANE protocol prioritizes patient’s contemporaneous refusal, while ED policy permits treatment under temporary incapacity). If you want both options defensible, explicitly note that neither policy clearly applies and that documentation requirements cannot be fully met overnight.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman presents to the ED within hours of a reported sexual assault. She is not using contraception and has previously told her OB clinician, documented in the chart, that she would not take post‑coital contraception because she views it as ending a potential pregnancy. In the ED she is oriented and not intoxicated. She has no head injury and a urine pregnancy test is negative. During a brief discussion she can repeat back that emergency contraception may reduce the chance of pregnancy if taken soon and that it can cause nausea. Her attention and stated preference fluctuate. When calm she declines it for the same moral reason. At other moments she becomes dissociated, says she is anxious about pregnancy from the assault, and tells you to “decide for me.” Her spouse confirms her prior stance but requests the medication. It is 3 AM. The patient plans to leave within 20 minutes. No advocate or psychiatry is available overnight, and the ED cannot dispense emergency contraception to take later. Hospital counsel advises that either giving it under temporary incapacity or withholding it based on her expressed refusal is legally permissible. You must decide before discharge.
data.choice_1: Administer emergency contraception tonight before discharge.
data.choice_2: Do not administer emergency contraception tonight.

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman presents to the ED within hours of a reported sexual assault. She is not using contraception and has previously told her OB clinician, documented in the chart, that she would not take post‑coital contraception because she views it as ending a potential pregnancy. In the ED she is oriented and not intoxicated. She has no head injury and a urine pregnancy test is negative. During a brief discussion she can repeat back that emergency contraception may reduce the chance of pregnancy if taken soon and that it can cause nausea. Her attention and stated preference fluctuate. When calm she declines it for the same moral reason. At other moments she becomes dissociated, says she is anxious about pregnancy from the assault, and tells you to “decide for me.” Her spouse confirms her prior stance but requests the medication. It is 3 AM. The patient plans to leave within 20 minutes. No advocate or psychiatry is available overnight, and the ED cannot dispense emergency contraception to take later. Hospital counsel advises that either giving it under temporary incapacity or withholding it based on her expressed refusal is legally permissible. You must decide before discharge.

choice_1.choice: Administer emergency contraception tonight before discharge.

choice_2.choice: Do not administer emergency contraception tonight.

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add one clause stating whether, at the moment of decision, you judge the patient has decision-making capacity (e.g., 'At discharge you determine she lacks capacity due to dissociation' or 'During a lucid interval she demonstrates capacity and clearly refuses/accepts emergency contraception').

Add a clause quantifying/clarifying the expected health/well-being benefit of preventing pregnancy (e.g., "she is mid‑cycle and very concerned a pregnancy would be psychologically devastating"), or conversely clarify that receiving emergency contraception against her stated moral belief would cause significant distress; without one of these, beneficence is not unambiguously in conflict across the two options.

Add one clause quantifying/characterizing the harm on each side (e.g., estimated pregnancy risk without EC and that an assault-related pregnancy would cause her severe distress; and that receiving EC against her stated moral belief would likely cause significant psychological/moral injury).

data.vignette: A 27-year-old woman presents to the ED within hours of a reported sexual assault. She is not using contraception. Her chart documents that she would not take post‑coital contraception because she views it as ending a potential pregnancy. She is oriented, not intoxicated, and has no head injury. A urine pregnancy test is negative. She can explain that emergency contraception is time-sensitive and may cause nausea. Her attention and preferences fluctuate. During a lucid interval she repeats her moral objection and declines the medication. Minutes later she becomes dissociated, says an assault-related pregnancy would be devastating, and asks you to decide for her. As discharge approaches, you judge she lacks decision-making capacity due to ongoing dissociation. Her spouse confirms her prior stance but requests the medication. It is 3 AM. She plans to leave within 20 minutes. No advocate or psychiatry is available, and the ED cannot dispense emergency contraception to take later. Hospital counsel advises either course is legally permissible. You must decide before discharge.

choice_1.choice: Administer emergency contraception tonight before discharge.

choice_2.choice: Do not administer emergency contraception tonight.
